CEVI is helping Geralyn obtain feed for her pigs. Now, Geralyn has access to credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage that CEVI gives to all its clients.

loans.use: To buy feed for her pigs and purchase fertilizers for her rice farm

loans.name: Lubajja Traders (C) Group

texts.en:
Huruna has been in the business of supplying coffee beans to factories in Mityana for about 10 years. He sells the beans from his 10-acre operation as well as coffee that he gathers from smaller operations. From his 10 acres, he is usually able to get two sacs of coffee per week.

Getting the coffee ready to sell is a time-consuming and laborious process. After picking the coffee pods, he lays them in the sun to dry. After they are dry, Huruna must crack open the individual pods and extract the coffee beans. Then he must pack these beans into large sacs and transport them to the factories to sell them.

Huruna has eight children ranging from 6 to 16 years old. They are all in school, so he and his wife have to search for ways to manage the large task of providing school fees for all of them. All of his children attend private schools. This is a sign that his business is making a difference in his family.

Huruna is requesting a loan of 2 million USH (UGX) to purchase sacs of coffee to resell. He says that if his business takes off, he would like to build some houses to rent to people in his community. His biggest dream is to travel around the world.

loans.use: To purchase sacs of coffee to resell

loans.name: Lois

texts.en:
Lois S. is 45 years old and a resident of Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She sells groceries from a store in her house. She sells items like cooked ingredients, sweets, and plastic products. Most of her clients are villagers who live near her house.

To help with the family's expenses, her husband works as a motorcycle taxi driver. The family has five children who are single and are studying in the secondary school.

S. is requesting a loan to buy a motorcycle to support her business. She will use the remainder of the loan to increase her grocery inventory.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen T. owns a small store. She is 48 years old and has 4 children. She sells a variety of goods in her village and earns a reasonable profit from her business. Her customers come from the same village. Most of them are her neighbors, friends, and passersby who are whiling away the time waiting for the next ride. In addition to her store, she also has a small rice farm. Her husband, Calixto T., is supportive of her and her business.

She is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for her business. The loan will help her to attract more customers and to earn more income for her family. She will also use the loan to buy fertilizer for her rice farm.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people start and run their own businesses. CEVI gives their clients credit assistance to run their businesses. They also provide training for the clients and insurance coverage to help them expand their small businesses.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia D. sells rice. She is 47 years old and owns a small farm that she has been tilling for 20 years. She married a farmer, Florentino D., Jr., and they have four children who attend school. School is quite expensive nowadays, so she and her husband work very hard to pay for the tuition, books and other miscellaneous school fees.

She is asking for a loan to buy six bags of urea fertilizer and rice seed. The loan will truly help her to achieve a better yield in her farm. In this way, she believes, she will have more rice to sell to support her family.

CEVI helps farmers to increase the size of their farm produce. CEVI clients are given not just credit, but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy six bags or urea fertilizer and rice seed

loans.name: Duk

texts.en:
A medium-sized stone house in Phnom Penh is the location of Mr. Duk S.'s home and grocery store. He usually buys produce in bulk from a marker supplier and sells it from his house. Normally, he can make average income of $6.00 per day. He has been running his business since early 2008.

His wife, SamArt, age 45, helps him with the business. She also sells a few vegetables in the market. The couple now has six children, four of whom still live with them in the family home.

Mr. S.'s investment is main source of income for the family and he recently sold all of the produce in his store. Therefore, he would like to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Balywunya Mixed Group

texts.en:
Sarah makes necklaces and bracelets through a program called Beads-4-life. She has also has a lively bar in Mukono. Sarah has been running her bar for about 10 years, but it was only about seven months ago that she began making jewelry.

To make her jewelry, Sarah uses beads that are made from paper that is dipped in glue. This style of beads is very common in Uganda. It is a day-long process to prepare the beads. First, she must cut and roll the paper, then she shapes each individual bead, and dips it in the glue mixture. After the beads are formed, they are left in the sun to dry overnight. The following day, Sarah will be able to make 10 necklaces and 10 bracelets.

Sarah sells her completed jewelry to some sellers in Kampala. She can sell her bracelets for 3,000 or 5,000 USH. Her necklaces range from 1,5000 to 6,000 USH. Since she buys her equipment for about 4,000 USH, she is able to make a nice profit from this new business venture.

Sarah and her husband have separated. She has two children who are both adults, but she looks after her five grandchildren. She provides for their daily needs while their parents work.

Today, Sarah is requesting a loan of 300,000 USH. With this loan, Sarah will restock her bar, buy crates of soda and beer, and also buy a few kilos of paper for her bead work.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for bead-making and restock her bar.

loans.name: Simaya

texts.en:
Simaya K. is currently in the business of selling beans, onions, tomatoes, etc., and is requesting a loan to build a shop.

Simaya is 37 years old and is married with a husband that is a chief. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build a shop

loans.name: Sadiya

texts.en:
Sadiya J. is currently in the business of selling clothes and bedsheets. She is requesting a loan to build a shop. Sadiya is 21 years old and married; her husband is a soldier. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build a shop

loans.name: Luzy

texts.en:
Luzy G. is currently in the business of selling tea, bread, and onions. She is requesting a loan to open a hotel. Luzy is 39 years old and married; her husband is a police officer. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for the family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build a hotel

loans.name: Queen

texts.en: Queen is 39 years old and she is married with seven children. She mills grains for customers and she also sells foodstuffs. She needs a loan of N100, 000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Junia

texts.en:
Junia P. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables, onions, and tomatoes, and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Junia is 32 years old and is married; her husband is a soldier. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Expand the business by building a shop

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria sells foodstuffs. She has been in this business for a long time. She needs a loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is 34 years old and married with a child. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Soeun M., 40, lives in a rural area of Pursat Province. She is a widowed mother who has four children; three of them are single and go to school, while the other one is married and lives separately. She currently sells Khmer noodle to her neighbors in the village. She frequently sells the noodles in the early morning, from 7 a.m. to 11 a.m.

As another income source, M. also raises pigs in a small stall next to her house. She is applying for a loan to buy five piglets to raise, and to upgrade her pigpen.

loans.use: To buy five piglets to raise

loans.name: Binta

texts.en: Binta sells cooked foods like rice, beans, eba, etc. She hopes to expand this business. She needs a loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She is 38 years old and married with seven children. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary E. is 36 years old and married with four children. She sells provisions and foodstuffs to people in her community. The demand for her provisions and foodstuffs is high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more provisions and foodstuffs  to sell. She is indeed grateful to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Nejua

texts.en:
Nejua R. is currently in the business of selling meat, rice, beans, etc. at the hotel. She is requesting a loan to expand the business. Nejua is 37 years old and widowed. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more tables and chairs

loans.name: Yaovi Éric

texts.fr: Monsieur S. yaovi éric a appris la couture, il a ouvert  son atelier de couture qu’il appelle « CHEZ ERIC LE ROI », il a commencé ce commerce depuis 1988 et il vend aussi des articles de mercerie, ce qui fait qu’il a une importante clientèle, actuellement son matériel de travail est vétuste, il a besoin d’un crédit pour renouveler son matériel de travail  ainsi avec ce nouveau crédit il achètera 01 machine à coudre, 01 sous compteur et des articles de mercerie. Il est marié et père de 02 enfants.
texts.en:
Mr. S. Yaovi Eric learned how to sew clothing. He opened a tailor’s shop he calls “CHEZ ERIC LE ROI”. He started this business in 1988, and he also sells supplies of the trade. As a result, he has a sizable number of customers. Right now, his equipment is antiquated. He needs a loan to renew his equipment. Thus, with this new loan, he will buy a sewing machine, a metering device, and tailoring supplies. He is married and the father of two children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a metering device and tailoring supplies

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce E. sells kitchen utensils. She hopes to expand this business. She needs the loan of N150,000 to purchase more kitchen utensils to sell. She is 47 years old and married with four children. She says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more kitchen utensils to sell

loans.name: Edithrudes

texts.en: Mrs. Edithrudes N. is 59 and married, with three children. When she was still in high school, her parents taught her to be more resourceful, finding ways to address her needs. When she got married, she always intended to venture into business and help her husband earn a living. At first, she cooked foods like pork, vegetables, and fish and sold it to their neighbors. Then she decided to join HSPFI and received PHP 10000 for her third loan. She used the fund to buy five head of pigs that were ready to be slaughtered. The raw products (pork) were delivered to their established customers as per their orders. With her ability to run the meat vending business, both she and her husband are more focused. As the business grows, they are getting more good customers. So she applied for her sixth loan in the amount of PHP17000 to purchase 10 head of pigs to meet the demands of her customers. She dreams of buying her own delivery truck to make her business easier and more convenient.

loans.use: To purchase 10 head of pigs

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda F. is a rice grower. She is 44 years old and has 6 children. Her husband is working abroad to support their family, especially their children's education. They met each other in Singapore and decided to get married in 1982. To help her husband, she is managing a small rice farm. The produce is what she uses to buy their other needs.

She is requesting a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy 4 bags of Urea, 2 bags Triple 14, also a fertilizer and pesticides to ensure good harvest in her farm. The loan will help her increase her yield. She wants to grow her business so that someday her husband won't need to work somewhere apart to support their family.

CEVI is helping Merlinda grow her business. Now she enjoys having CEVI credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage services.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Anitha

texts.en:
Anitha is 30 years old, widowed, and has two children (twins) age 10. She also cares for four additional dependents.

Anitha has been a bites and cooking oil seller in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for 5 years. She belongs to the Namba Tatu loan group. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $75. Every day she works at her business for three hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more wheat flour, sugar and cooking oil to improve her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy more wheat flour, sugar and cooking oil to improve her business

loans.name: Jesline

texts.en:
Jesline A. is 40 years old and is widowed. She has four children and her children go to school.

Jesline is currently in the business of selling beans, tomatoes, and charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand the business. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace D. is currently in the business of selling cooking oil and is requesting a loan to build a shop. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

Grace is 30 years old and is married with a husband that is a teacher. She has three children and her children go to school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build a shop

loans.name: Crisnan

texts.en:
Crisnan M. owns a small "sari-sari" store. She is 52 years old and has only 1 child. She started her business since marrying her husband, Elmer M.. Aside from the store, she also owns a van. Her husband is using it for passengers and additional income for the family. She wants to buy another van to augment their income. They also farm. They grow rice and sell all their produce to rice traders.

She is requesting a loan of Php 5,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and additional stock for her sari-sari store business. Her loan will help her grow her store and improve the soil on her farm.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people start and have their own business. They not only provide their clients credit assistance, but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and additional stock for her sari-sari store business.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
As a working mother, Teresita B. manages to devote her time to both family and business. She needs to double her effort just to make sure that all the needs of the family are met. Her husband died, leaving her with 3 kids to raise. With her present business, she knows that she is able to provide and give her family what they are due.

She is a banana cue and vegetable viand vendor during the day and a Balut (processed duck eggs - a Filipino aphrodisiac) vendor at night. Her humble desire is to let her children (who are attending college, high school and elementary school) finish their studies and to have a business that is sustainable and productive so they can have a stable source of living. She is in need of PHP 14,000.00 to finance her business.

loans.use: To purchase eggs, bananas and vegetables for her business

loans.name: Fazilat

texts.ru: Фазилат 50 лет, она замужем и имеет 3 детей. Фазилат предприниматель и занимается куплей продажей детской одежды и обуви на разных рынках. Опыт Фазилат в этой деятельности уже несколько лет, но до этого она не получала займы. Так как весна наступила, и многие виды одежды зимние, то Фазилат хочет обновить весенний ассортимент. Сейчас она собирается получить займ чтобы расширить свой бизнес и погасит в течении 6 месяцев.
texts.en:
Fazilat is 50 years old, she is married and has 3 children. Fazilat is an entrepreneur and purchases and sells children’s clothing and shoes at different markets. Fazilat already has several years of experience in this area, but has not taken out a loan until now. Since spring has started and a wide variety of clothing is for the winter, Fazilat would like to update her spring assortment. Right now she plans to take out a loan to expand her business and to pay it back over 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand spring clothing inventory

loans.name: Lusia

texts.en:
Lusia has owned a small food vendor store in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for 15 years. She belongs to Semtema South group loan. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items in order to improve her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Lusia is 31 years old, divorced, and has two children aged 14 and 9. She also cares for one additional dependent.

loans.use: To buy more food items in order to improve her business

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda G. is managing a small farm. She grows rice and almost all her produce is intended for family use. The remainder of her produce is sold to rice traders for additional income for the family. She is 50 years old and has three children. Her husband is a farmer who has managed their 1-hectare farm since they are married.

Yolanda is requesting a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizer, seed,  and pesticides. The loan will help improve the soil in her farm and provide the whole family with a bountiful harvest.

CEVI provides Yolanda the credit assistance that she needs. Yolanda also receives training and insurance coverage to help her grow her farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seed, and pesticides

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en:
Betty B. is the leader of Zibula Atudde group in Mityana. She is a hard working lady with a retail shop as her business.

This is her fourth loan that she is taking from Pearl Microfinance. Betty is glad to say that before she started getting loans, her income was so low, but now she is able to make a weekly gross profit of 200,000 Ushs.

She was able to increase stock in her shop that is located in Mityana as well as being able to buy more household items that are helpful to her family.

Betty needs another loan to be able to stock her shop with more products.

loans.use: Buy more stock for her shop.

loans.name: Laylo

texts.ru: Лайло занимается куплей продажей косточек от абрикосов на местных рынках Исфары. Оборот ее бизнеса небольшой, но Лайло работает над тем чтобы увеличить свой бизнес. Лайло 39 лет, имеет 3 детей, ее муж находится на заработках в России. В МикроИнвест Лайло пришла недавно и узнав про условия кредитования решила подать заявку на займ. Первая сумма небольшая и если понравиться то она дальше будет увеличивать суммы и надеется значительно расширить свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Laylo purchases and sells apricot pits at the local markets of Isfara. Her turnover is not large, but Laylo is working on growing her business. Laylo is 39 years old, has 3 children and her husband is a migrant worker in Russia. Laylo came to MicroInvest recently and after finding out about the credit terms decided to apply for a loan. Her first sum is small and if she likes it, she will further increase her loan amounts and hopes to significantly expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Donata

texts.en:
Donata has been a bites and charcoal seller in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for eight years. She belongs to Mwenge West group loan (Group code: 2020). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Every day she works at her business for nine hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy more charcoal for sale and wheat flour, sugar and cooking oil for bites preparation to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and help her grow her business.

Donatha is married and has four children,ages 19, 14, 11 and 7. She also cares for four additional defendants.

loans.use: Buy more charcoal, wheat flour, sugar and cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Marian

texts.en:
Marian sells underwear, ready made and baby items. She has been in this business since 1998.

Marian travels to Idumota (Lagos) to buy her underwear, ready made and baby items in wholesale and sells to retailers in her locality.

Marian is hard working, very optimistic about the future of her business and that of her immediate family. She is 40 years old and married with five children. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more underwear, baby items, and ready made to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: Purchase underwear, ready made and baby items to sell.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda F.'s life is in the soil. She is a farmer who grows rice for a living. Her husband, Narciso F. tills the land for them. They have two children who are in school. Luzviminda wants to support her children's educational needs so that when they grow up, they will have better jobs and be able to support their future families.

Luzviminda is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use a loan to purchase fertilizer. The fertilizer will improve the soil condition of her farm. In that way, she believes, she could have better yield for the next harvest season.

CEVI is helping more farmers sustain their livelihood. CEVI gives their clients credit, training, and insurance coverage services to help their small businesses to grow.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Hilda has been a local alcohol seller in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for 10 years. She belongs to Semtema "B" West group (Group code: 2002). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $110. Every day she works at her business for nine hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more local alcohol for her business. Hilda is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Hilda is 36 years old, married, and has six children, ages 18, 13, 9, 8, 5 and 3. She also cares for six additional dependants.

loans.use: Buy more local alcohol to sell.

loans.name: Chinyere

texts.en:
Visiting Chinyere, it was discovered that her place of business is one of the most attractive drinking spot in her locality.

Chinyere prepares pepper soup and cooked food along with drinks in her shop. She was able to distinguish herself from her competitors. Chinyere is 41 years old and married with four children.

Chinyere has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past two years, and this little loan has tremendously increased her business and her profitability. She needs a loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuff and drinks to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: Purchase more foodstuff and drinks to sell

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna F. owns a small "sari-sari" store and sells various kinds of goods like rice, soap, vinegar, instant noodles, milk, sugar, shampoo, coke, and other products. She is 52 years old and single. She started her business in 2002. This store provides her with the money she needs for her daily expenses. She is not looking for a husband anymore. She just wants to grow her business and help her siblings and their families.

Edna is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizer, feed for the pigs, and additional stock for her store. The loan will help her attract more customers, sell more items, and earn more income.

CEVI helps her grow her business. She receives credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to help her and her small business to flourish.

loans.use: Purchase  fertilizer, feed for the pigs, and additional stock for her store

loans.name: Grace's Group

texts.en:
M. Grace is the leader of Byantuuyo group in Jinja. She is a hard working lady with a hotel/restaurant/bar business that she has been running for over five years and the same premise. She prepares breakfast, lunch and supper and in the evenings, people gather and have a cold beer just to relax from a hard day’s work.

From her businesses, she has been able to pay school fees for her five children, feed them as well as save money. She again needs a loan to be able to buy more food stuffs and drinks for her restaurant and bar.

loans.use: Buy more food stuffs and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha has owned a small food vendor store for four years. She also sells bites in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa.

She belongs to Semtema "A" West group loan (Group code: 2022). Martha currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works at her business for 13 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Martha is 29 years old, married, and has three children, ages 9, 5 and 1. She also cares for five additional dependants.

loans.use: Buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema has been a clothes seller in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for five years. She belongs to Mkimbizi "A" East loan group (Group code: 2015). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy more clothes for resale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Rehema is 29 years old, married, and has two children, ages 11 and 5. She also cares for two additional dependants.

loans.use: Buy more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Melodina

texts.en:
Melodina G. manages a small rice farm. She sells rice to support her family. She is 55 years old, a widow, and has two children. When she is not busy in her rice farm, she sells dried fish to her neighbors to augment their limited family income. She is currently a barangay (village) counselor, so she is involved in politics as well farming.

Melodina is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer for her farm. She is also willing to venture into other lines of business. Aside from selling dried fish and rice, she is also thinking of starting a food business to better support her family.

CEVI helps Melodina start a new business and grow her rice farm. She is given credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage, which CEVI provides to all its clients.

loans.use: To purchase  fertilizer

loans.name: Henry's Group

texts.en:
M. Henry is the leader of the Byantuyo group in Jinja. He is a farmer and his income generating business sells produce that he grows on his plantation, like matooke, sweet potatoes, cassava, maize, beans and so on.

He has loyal customers. When he does not have enough to sell, he buys from fellow farmers around his village and neighboring ones, to make sure his customers do not meander.

He needs a loan to be able to buy more produce for sale and to employ manpower to help him clear more land for fresh farming.

loans.use: Buy more produce to sell and employ labor on his farm.

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
Asia has been a fish seller in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for six years. She belongs to Mkimbizi "A" West loan group (Group code 2019). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $110. Every day she works at her business for nine hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy more fish for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, improve her home and pay school fees for her children.

Asia is 27 years old, married, and has three children, ages 9, 5 and 2. She also cares for four additional dependants.

loans.use: Buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Oluwatoyin

texts.en:
Oluwatoyin is 33 years old and married with 3 children. She is business oriented. She sells block in her house and she is able to invest the profit back in to her business for the continuous growth of her business. Oluwatoyin has been in this business for the past 8 years and she has been borrowing from LAPO microfinance for the past 3 years.

Oluwatoyin wants to expand her business by selling jewelry and second-hand clothes. She will be able to achieve this with the Kiva loan of N100,000 that she is requesting. Oluwatoyin is very happy and grateful for the financial support given to her by LAPO Microfinance and Kiva lenders. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase jewelry and second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en:
Kemi sells provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs. She acquired the skill from her mother beginning in childhood, and she now has more experience in selling her provisions and drinks. Kemi has been in the business for the past 20 years. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years, and she has been able to invest the loans in her business.

Kemi is 42 years old and married, with four children. Kemi lives in Dopemu. She is requesting a loan of N140,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina has owned a small shop in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for 6 years. She is a bites (snacks) seller. She belongs to Mkimbizi "A" west group loan (group code 2019).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Every day she works at her business for 11 hours.  

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items in order to increase her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  

Christina is 50 years old, married, and has nine children, ages 32, 30, 28, 26, 24, 22, 20, 18 and 16. She also cares for nine additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more items in order to increase her current stock.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena A. is forty-eight years old. She is married and has one child, a boy. He is currently pursuing a degree programme in one of the public universities in Ghana. She works to help her husband financially to take care of the family. She lives with her husband and son in a rented apartment in Mampong in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Her husband is a public servant.

Abena deals in all kinds of textiles – shirts, shorts, pants, etc. She deals mostly in children's clothing. She buys from Kumasi and sells in her community. She also treks to villages to sell. Abena has been in business for twenty-four years and wants a loan to procure more bales of textiles. She is hoping to improve her living standard.

loans.use: To buy additional clothes for resale
